channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Head of Inquiry Into Child Abuse in Britain Faces a Legal Challenge
item.description: Fiona Woolf, the head of the inquiry, faces scrutiny over her links to the man who was home secretary when files about the abuse charges vanished.
item.dc:creator: By KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: A Banner on a Hong Kong Landmark Speaks of Democracy and Identity
item.description: The group that unfurled the banner, calling for free elections, from a prominent feature of the Hong Kong landscape said it was drawing attention to how the city was not just about money but also about spirit.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Supporters of the Hong Kong pro-democracy movement hung a banner on Kowloon's iconic Lion Rock with the message "I want genuine universal suffrage" under the movement's yellow umbrella symbol.

item.title: Nathan Cirillo, Soldier Killed in Ottawa, Used Strength to Help Others
item.description: Corporal Cirillo, 25, was a gym buff with a fondness for rescue dogs and the proud father of a boy who just started kindergarten.
item.dc:creator: By SARAH MASLIN NIR
item.media:credit: Corporal Mélani Girard/The Canadian Armed Forces
item.media:description: Cpl. Nathan Cirillo at the tomb of the Unknown Soldier in Ottawa a few days before his death.

item.title: Lebanon to Bar Syrian Refugees
item.description: Lebanon announced that it would not accept any more refugees from neighboring Syria, except in what the authorities deem to be “exceptional” cases.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: In Mexico, an Embattled Governor Resigns
item.description: The leader of the southern Mexico state where 43 college students have gone missing stepped down on Thursday under pressure from his own party.
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD

item.title: Robust Reponse to ISIS Appears Far Off for Iraqis
item.description: Despite increasing assistance from the United States, Iraq’s ability to mount a sustained counteroffensive to retake territory seized by the Islamic State is still months away, American officials say.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: Kurdish troops killed fighting Islamic State militants in Syria were buried in Suruc, Turkey. Iraqis and Kurds have reclaimed some territory, but their ability to sustain advances is in doubt.

item.title: U.S. Is Investigating Report That Islamic State Used Chlorine Gas
item.description: American officials said they were examining a report that 11 police officers were sickened after a bomb dispersed chlorine gas last month near Balad, north of Baghdad.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By KIRK SEMPLE and ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: After Shooting, Fear and Anxiety Take Over Ottawa
item.description: Workers in the capital were stuck in their buildings during a lockdown after shootings at two sites on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN and JEFF Z. KLEIN
item.media:credit: Adrian Wyld/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Members of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police at the Parliament building on Wednesday.

item.title: Khenpo Kartse, Tibetan Religious Leader, Is Said to Be Sentenced in China
item.description: The well-known figure had been accused of harboring a fugitive monk from Chamdo in his own monastery in the Yushu area of Qinghai Province.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: Britain Pledges Millions to Fight Ebola and Chides Others to Spend More
item.description: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain said his country had already promised more aid than any other in Europe to fight Ebola in West Africa, but said, “we need other European countries to do more.”
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER and ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:description: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain is to promise an additional 80 million pounds to build treatment centers.

item.title: Ottawa Gunman, Despite Past, Was Not Identified as Threat
item.description: The Canadian police acknowledged that the man who killed a soldier at a war memorial was not identified as a security threat despite a criminal record in three cities, embrace of extremist ideas and intent to travel to Syria.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN and SARAH MASLIN NIR
item.media:description: A woman stood next to flowers left at the War Memorial on Thursday in Ottawa.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Shattering the Peace on Parliament Hill
item.description: A gunman exploits the openness at the heart of Canada’s democracy.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL PETROU

item.title: Jihadist Captive Faces Terror Charges in U.S.
item.description: The former Russian soldier who joined mujahedeen fighters during Russia’s war in Afghanistan in 1980s also later fought against American troops until his capture in 2009.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MATT APUZZO

item.title: In Iraq, Relief After News of Blackwater Convictions
item.description: For many of the survivors of the 2007 shooting in Baghdad, the verdicts offered some solace after a traumatic event that became synonymous with the worst of the American occupation.
item.dc:creator: By KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: Unable to Marry Gay Couples, Some Italian Mayors Rebel
item.description: Local leaders aim to force national legislators to clarify the legal standing of same-sex couples who have married abroad.
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: By GAIA PIANIGIANI
item.media:credit: Paolo Marchetti for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mayor Ignazio Marino, center, registered the foreign marriage of Tommaso Giartosio, left, and Gianfranco Goretti.

item.title: British Labour Chief, a Jew Who Criticizes Israel, Walks a Fine Line
item.description: The politically loaded issue of support for Israel comes with a personal dimension for Ed Miliband, who could become Britain’s prime minister after next year’s election.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:description: Ed Miliband, who could become Britain’s first Jewish-born prime minister since Disraeli, has denounced Israeli actions in Gaza.

item.title: Boko Haram Said to Abduct More Women
item.description: A bishop described a situation much like the one last April when more than 200 schoolgirls were taken in a kidnapping that attracted worldwide attention.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: Ottawa Gunman’s Family Releases Statement
item.description: The parents of Michael Zehaf-Bibeau, the man authorities identified as the gunman, expressed grief over the shooting.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: U.N. Human Rights Panel Urges China To Allow Free Elections in Hong Kong
item.description: A rights panel in Geneva said that officials needed to do more to ensure that people are allowed to vote as well stand for elections.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:description: Pro-democracy demonstrators in Hong Kong's Mong Kok neighborhood on Thursday.

item.title: Beijing Formally Charges Writer Who Published Memoirs of Victims of Mao Era
item.description: Tie Liu, 81, who has been held in a detention center since September, was charged with two crimes: illegal business activities and “creating a disturbance.”
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Listening Post: Latest North Korean Mystery: A Diplomatic Charm Offensive
item.description: A series of gestures by the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, most dramatically the release of an imprisoned American tourist, has raised hopes of a rapprochement with the United States.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: North Korea’s main party newspaper, Rodong Sinmun, released an undated image of the country's leader, Kim Jong-un, seen using a cane while touring a housing complex for scientists in Pyongyang.

item.title: U.S. Strikes Cut Into ISIS Oil Revenues, Treasury Official Says
item.description: David S. Cohen, the government’s point man on Islamic State finances, said American airstrikes on refineries controlled by the group had threatened its supply network.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS

item.title: Violence in Pakistan Kills at Least 13
item.description: Three separate assaults each reflected a different facet of the violence afflicting Baluchistan Province — ethnic tension, religious extremism and separatism.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: At Least 500 Militants Killed in U.S.-Led Strikes in Syria, Observer Group Says
item.description: The group, the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights, also said the strikes, which started on Sept. 23, have killed at least 32 civilians.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Video: Inside the Ebola Ward
item.description: The daily challenges faced by doctors, nurses and other workers at the Ebola treatment center run by the International Medical Corps in Bong County, Liberia.
item.dc:creator: By BEN C. SOLOMON
